Method Detail

find

public static boolean find(int[][] mat,
                           int x)
Q2 - A method that returns "true" if and only if a value is in the sorted matrix. Time Complexity - O(log(n)) : binary search - each iteration the search area on the matrix is minimized by half. Space Complexity - O(1) : the amount of memory that used is constant and does not depends on the data that it is processing.

Parameters:
mat[][] - - 2D sorted array in size of n^2 where n=2^k.
x - an integer to serach
Returns:
True if x was found. False if x was NOT found.

isSink

public static int isSink(int[][] mat)
Q1 - "sink" : The values of the line[k] are all 0 and values of the column[k] are all 1 (exept [k][k]. Time Complexity - O(n) : one while loop that depends on the array length. Space Complexity - O(1) : the amount of memory that used is constant and does not depends on the data that it is processing.

Parameters:
mat[][] - - 2D array in size of nXn full of 0 and 1.
Returns:
The "sink" index.

isSumOf

public static boolean isSumOf(int[] s,
                              int n)
Q3 - A recursive methood that accepts set of natural numbers and a natural number n, and returns true if n is the sum out of the set. Otherwise, the method will return false

Parameters:
s[] - array of natural numbers different from each other.
n - key to compare to.
Returns:
True is n is sum of s[], False otherwise.

numPaths

public static int numPaths(int[][] mat,
                           int x1,
                           int y1,
                           int x2,
                           int y2)
Q4 - A 'path' is a a series of cells in a 2D array: A. The first cell in the series is ([x1][y1]) B. The last cell in the series is ([x2] [y2]) C. The passage from a cell is only to its neighbors: Above him, Below him, to his right and to his left. D. Each cell in the array appears at most a single time in the route

Parameters:
mat - A 2D Array of positive integers.
x1,y1,x2,y2 - Array cells located above the main diagonal (mat[i][i]).
Returns:
The number of 'paths' that do not cross the main diagonal (but may contain cells located in this diagonal) that exist between the two cells.
